author: JamieBass

description.text: I created a Spatula for an everyday item. A person often uses it for their cooking.

Step 1

I create rectangle, long enough for the handle of the spatula.

Step 2

I then created a square and place it on top of the rectangle.

Step 3

I then choose the arc tool, the 2 point arc, then I created a arc on each corner of the square.

Step 4

I then choose the eraser tool to delete the outer object of the arc.

step 5

I created 6 lines and place them even in the square.

Step 6

I added circles in the middle of the lines, on top and on the bottom, made sure they touch the both lines.

Step 7

I used the line tool to cut across the circle, touching the both lines also.

Step 8

Then I used the eraser tool to delete the objects inside the lines to create a curve.
I liked the ziptie approach because it's simple. I just modified it to work on my 3d printer. The SCAD file is sloppily thrown together, but I uploaded it anyways if you want it.

This is awesome. thats it

this is not an exact model but the closest you can get

title: Customizable Fan Duct System - for Quadcopters.

description.text:
This is a customizable module that I've been working on to allow you to build a propeller duct system. It is research based and should give you a noticeable improvement in duration and/or power from your system (if you can keep it fairly light and stick close to the referenced figures).

The module is for use in a ducted quad-copter that I'm designing, but as ever I like to share my modules in case it makes anyone's life easier with their designs.

If you need more details that aren't obvious in the Customizer app have a look in the .SCAD file itself - I've put a fairly serious key in about all the variables at the top of the file.

HOVER AND WIND-TUNNEL TESTING OF SHROUDED ROTORS FOR IMPROVED MICRO AIR VEHICLE DESIGN
~ Jason L. Pereira Doctor of Philosophy, 2008.

https://capolight.wordpress.com/2015/01/14/quadcopter-rotor-duct/
~ Richard (?).

A big thanks to both of them for their work on this subject.

author: beta_ready

description.text: This is a reasonably heavy duty FPV quadcopter with some spare capacity for extra batteries or payload.  Blender models, STLs, and component shopping lists are all included in the downloads.

This project arose after reading a great article by Darren Yates (http://darrenyates.com.au/tag/building-a-quadcopter) in the TechLife Magazine (August 2013 issue). I suddenly felt inspired, and so settled down to designing a new Quadcopter using similar components to those recommended in the article, but using a slightly better quality transmitter, adding FPV and using more powerful selections for the powertrain. The motor and ESC selection came from one of the recommended options for the Aeroquad open source project (http://aeroquad.com). This selection dictated the prop size and pitch. I was also keen to build the frame on the 3D Printer so that it incorporated all of the features I wanted to include. I found that Darren's recommended flight controller was available on HobbyKing at the time so I quickly designed up the rest of the electrical system and got my order in. I have included a list of the components selected for the project in the downloadable files. The list is comprehensive and covers what you need if you were to build this project from having zero radio control equipment to hand. The only missing item of significance from this list is the FPV video viewing device as there are quite a few options available and potentially something you may already have to hand. I would recommend for this the monitor sold by FoxtechFPV which incorporates a diversity receiver this will give you a tidy package that avoids the need for the seperate FPV receiver and asociated fittings. The printed parts were designed in Blender 2.58 and printed on an Ultimaker. Thanks to Zampik (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117430) and MechTonic (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22071) for the inspiration from their designs. The Blender model is included in the downloads to help with assembly or modification. For Non-Blender users there is also a 3DS version in the downloads. STLs have all been tested in Slic3R. Generally I used a 25% fill but the lightly loaded bits such as the feet and top deck were done with a 10% fill. I have included an image and pdf of the small bracket that holds the FPV transmitter on. This is designed to be cut from a piece of plastic bottle and screwed + glued to the back of the two printed FPVtransmitter cradle sections. Bike inner tube rubber and packing foam have been used to back some of the electronic components, and provide soft washers. Plastic tubing has been used to line the top parts of the M4 rods and keep the ESC cables away. Velco ties firmly hold the battery in its cradle, and cable ties have been used extensively to hold components in place and tidy up the wiring. The camera, the reciever and the FPV transmitter are held into their brackets using cable ties. I recommend clearing out all holes with either a 3.2 or3.5mm drill bit for those designed for the M3 screws or a 4.5mm drill bit for the holes designed to take the four M4 threaded rods. Nylon lock nuts should be used on the M4 rods and the M3 bolts holding the controller onto the top deck. There are quite a few places where recesses have been designed for M3 nuts. These are a snug fit when printed on the Ultimaker but may require clearing with a knife for other printers. The landing feet also have a couple of slots each for M4 nuts. Put the nuts in the slots then clip the landing feet into the aluminium channel to trap them. You will then be able to screw the M4 machine screws into them to hold the whole lot in place. The Power Distribution board supplied by HobbyKing and included in the list of items is a really useful piece of kit BUT it's current rating is not high enough for the currents drawn by the ESCs at full power. I added in some relatively heavy copper wire (powercord cable) between the connectors to carry the additional current. It's a bit ugly but seems to work. I thoroughly recommend getting hold of a simulator. Admittedly they are expensive but they are realistic and allow you to develop your automatic skills at flying Radio Control aircraft and 'copters. The expense is easily offset by saving yourself the time you would otherwise spend repairing and fixing your planes after crashing. I use RealFlight from Towerhobbies, but if you have the right transmitter PhoenixRC is also an excellent simulator. Hobbyking have a simulator based on the open source FMS (Flying Model Simulator) which is not bad and will certainly help but doesn't quite have the same level of realism as the other two. I think I am off-topic. Enjoy the project if you make one yourself, and thanks for looking. Regards
Hamish

comments.author: bluemelon

comments.text:
Hi Bluemelon
When I designed the thing I had the whole thing rotated 45 degrees from where it is now so that the arms were all along the axis. The overall dimensions were just from the properties box of for the object, and I was just keying in the number of blender units I wanted for any extrude, hole radius, hole depths, and moves. If i wanted to locate anything like a hole accurately in a face I would line it up with an edge or corner from which I wanted to offset it from then just move it with keyed in values to get the offset in millimetres. Very rarely did I use the measure function which, in the Blender versions I was using, were a bit lacking in usefulness. I believe the measure tool boxes have improved somewhat in the latest versions of Blender.

comments.text:
Hi julvr
Good questions. Each motor has about 1kg of thrust and If I recall correctly last time I weighed the quadcopter it was about 1.5kg all up with a 5000mAh battery onboard. So there is stacks of carrying capacity. I would presume your GoPro plus rig to secure it would not weigh more than 300-400g anyway.
I have had quite a few problems with the control system randomly glitching which has meant that i have not had the craft airborne continuously for the entire life of the 5000mAh battery. Having said that it has provided at least 15 minutes total flight time when it has behaved itself. Someone I met while flying a plane at a local park the other week said that he had had the same problem with motors dropping out and got around it by reprogramming the ESCs to think they were on NiMH batteries instead of LiPOs thereby preventing the ESCs dropping out too early.- I have yet to try this solution.
As far as performance in the wind goes, I have not had too much success with that of late (which is a major limitation of flying in a gusty and windy city like Wellington New Zealand). The problem is related to the drop out of the motors as they power up to stabilise the quad and then drop out because of perceived low battery voltage. So in answer to your question, I would say that the controller I have on board and the settings I am currently running mean that it is not all that stable. Hopefully some of the things I intend to try to fix the motor drop out problem and controller tuning will sort that out.
Finally, your question has prompted me to get off my butt and post up the modified version of this which is a bit more robust. The outrigger landing pads on this design are very vulnerable to moderately heavy landings. The new design gets rid of those and replaces them with a could of bent wire skids that act as the landing gear and better protect the battery. I have also redesigned the battery holder to battery locate the battery and also has provision for some front and back facing lights so that it is easier to see which way the machine is facing when not flying FPV. Anyway look out for that, I'll try to get it up within the next week. .
comments.author: BouncyMonkey

comments.text: On the battery drop out issue, after much hunting around reading forums and things I eventually found out that one of the ESC to motor solder joints was just slightly less than perfect.  Resoldering it solved the problem and it has been flying reliably since.

author: 3dbeta

title: DIY: Mayor Harold Washington Bust Scan at Chicago Public Library

description.text:
DIY: Mayor Harold Washington Bust

In honor of the Harold Washington Summit, we’ve created a 3D scan of the late mayor in the Maker Lab.

How We Made It-
Using photographs, 3D scanning technology and free CAD software, the Maker Lab team recreated a copy of the bust of Harold Washington that’s proudly displayed in the State Street Corridor of Harold Washington Library Center. The original artwork was created by sculptor Abelardo Ghoulam in 1988 out of a substance called marbeline and later cast in bronze.

To create the 3D model, we started by taking high-quality photos of the original sculpture using a Canon DSLR camera and did a 3D scan with an Xbox Kinect. Then we used 123D Catch, Blender and Sculptris (all free software programs) to compile the images and incorporate as much detail as possible from the original. Finally, we printed it out using our Makerbot Replicator 2 3D printer.

Make It Yourself-
If you would like to create a tiny Mayor Washington (or use our model in another art piece), you can download the file or find it on Thingiverse. Once you’re ready to print, join us in the Maker Lab during Open Shop to make your mini-mayor!

Thanks to the team who made it happen--John Christensen, Emily Faulkner, Jorge Garcia, Glenn Humphries, Tommy Stanton, and Morag Walsh!

title: Star Trek - The Next Generation Constellation Class Cruiser

description.text:
Siccome mi sono accorto che nella mia Delta c'è bisogno di un po' di luce mentre stampa, ho recuperato 6 LED Strip lunghi 10cm da 12V (a luce bianca ovviamente) ed ho pensato un modo pratico e semplice per fissarli alla Delta senza comprometterne i movimenti e gli ingombri.

Ho realizzato un supporto, che verrà (almeno nel mio caso) moltiplicato per sei e fissato ai lati di ogni torre della Delta. Siccome a me piace la luce ho pensato di fissare due strip LED per ogni torre, da cui il numero iniziale.

Ho pensato poi di dotare il supporto di una slitta per accogliere un rifrattore che serve appunto a diffondere la luce e a renderla più "morbida" e meno fastidiosa per chi è davanti alla stampante.

Anche se in rete di supporti per strip LED già fatti ne esistono di vario genere, questo a mio parere è particolare, perlomeno per me visto che l'ho realizzato da zero, in quanto ha la possibilità di essere dotato di un rifrattore ottico che lo rende anche più gradevole alla vista e più "professionale".

Stampa del Supporto StripLED: Preferibilmente in verticale, per garantire una maggiore precisione nelle guide.

Stampa del Rifrattore: Preferibilmente sdraiato sul lato più lungo in modo tale che la "grofronatura" della superficie filtrante rimanga liscia verso l'esterno e piacevolmente zigrinata verso l'interno. Ovviamente almeno questo pezzo va stampato con un filamento TRASPARENTE. (Suggerisco un colore neutro).

Questi supporti possono essere installati anche su stampanti di diverso tipo (Prusa, Mendelmax etc etc) è sufficiente fissare il tutto con due viti M3. I miei supporti sono comunque pensati per essere fissati a dei profilati Bosch 20x20mm.

Enrico.

Because I realized that in my Delta we need a little 'light while printing, I have recovered 6 LED Strip 10cm long 12V (white light of course), and I thought a practical and easy way to fix the Delta without compromising the movements and overall dimensions.

I realized a support, which will be (at least in my case) multiplied by six, and fixed to the sides of each of the Delta tower. Because I like the light I thought I would attach two LED strips for each tower, from which the initial number.

I then thought of providing the support of a slide to accommodate a refractor which serves precisely to diffuse the light and to make it more "soft" and less troublesome for those who is in front of the printer.

Even if the network supports for LED strips already made there are of various kinds, in my opinion this is particularly, at least for me because I made from scratch, as it has the possibility of being equipped with an optical refractor which It makes it more pleasant to the eye and more "professional".

Print StripLED Support: Preferably vertically, to ensure greater precision in the guides.

Release of the refractor: Preferably lying on the longer side in such a way that the "grofronatura" of the filtering surface remains smooth outwardly knurled and pleasantly inward. Obviously least this piece is printed with a TRANSPARENT filament. (I suggest a neutral color).

These supports can be installed on different types (Prusa printers, Mendelmax etc etc) is enough secure with two M3 screws. My media is still designed to be secured to the profiles 20x20mm Bosch.

Enrico.

The one I made for my own use required two little srews to fix the top part on the bottom part.
I just fixed this issue by adding a pin to print.

Have fun with it!

You need another extend?

No problem, send me a note or leave a comment and I will check to create it.

Last but not least, I would love to see any other prints of this item, so if you printed out, I would be glad if you would upload some pictures to the "I made" section.

remixed_from.title: X Axis Belt Tensioner for Wanhao i3, Monoprice Maker Select, Cocoon Create etc.

title: Wanhao i3 X-Axis Belt Tensioner with offset

description.text:
This is based on the Wanhao i3 X-Axis Belt Tensioner (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1206926) designed by Heathicus (http://www.thingiverse.com/Heathicus)

I'm running some IGUS style printed PLA bushings (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24990) in a SCS8UU block (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1172838)

The original design had my bottom belt of centre - this would then cause the belt to rub against the pulley when the carriage got close to the edge on the opposite side to the endstop.

To fix this I moved the mount block 2mm out causing the belt to run parallel under the upper belt run.

After buying a Parrot Bebop 2, SkyController and official Parrot Bebop backpack, I realized a problem... The drone wouldn't fit in the backpack with the props attached, and there wasn't a good way to store them in the backpack. After using the container that replacement props ship in and even the sunshade as a way to protect them, I decided to make this.

The case is thick and pretty sturdy with enough room for 4 propellers, with just enough room to slide them in and out without them getting stuck and warping. While not airtight, the lid will keep large debris out and is thin and reinforced to prevent warping. The tabs at the ends of the lid keep it in place, relying on FFF printing to help secure it.

The box has small cutouts on the ends along the top edge, allowing you to pry the lid off using your fingernail. Nothing overly complicated.

title: sunhokey xcarriage and bowden E3D mount

description.text:
Replacement x carriage for Sunhokey Prusa I3.

The goal of this design is to create a more rigid platform for the hotend to be mounted on.
To achieve this I decided to use ball bearings instead of linear ones and use screws to tweak the amount of pressure on the track in order to get as much of the play out as possible.
I think it came out well.
There are some touch ups to do here and there but nothing major.
[Update 2016-05-06] Added mount point for M4 Allen screw on both sides to be used as end stop trigger.

During working on this design I found the "E3D v6 Bowden X-carriage mount Prusa i3" by Tech2C ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706 ). Since this really nice hotend mount did all I wanted, I modified it to fit my X carriage instead of designing my own from scratch.
Many thanks to Tech2C.

I got inspiration for using ball bearings from "Bearing block for 8 mm shaft, 3 x 623zz bearings at 120 degrees" by good_idea ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1424346 ). Although in the end I did it in a different way, I'd still like to mention the influence. Also I used good_ideas design on my printer while printing these parts, as the original linear bearings were just not up to par.

What you'll need:
8 Ball bearings 624zz
4 Ball bearings 623zz (I did not fit them though, but you can)
8 Allen screws m4 16mm
6 Allen screws m4 20mm
6 m4 nuts
4 Allen screws m3 16mm
4 m3 nuts

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

I printed the mine at 0.2 mm with PLA at a speed of 35mm/s

I drilled the holes for 4mm to 3.5 mm after print.
Other holes might need drilling as well.

comments.text: Eadric, thank you very much for the reference. Just to mention. I have designed separate blocks and not the whole x-carriage (so far)  for several reasons:
comments.author: good_idea

comments.text: What advantage does this design have as opposed to the linear bearing version? more work?
comments.author: mariarti

comments.text:
I found this setup to be much more stable than the original linear bearings.
Also as the running surface is larger wear should be less, but I have not had enough time to give any real data on that.
Finally with the top and bottom screws it is possible to adjust the tension on rods, this helps find the balance between play and smooth light movement.
comments.author: mariarti

comments.text:
Yeah, I bet it rolls smoother than linear bearings, at the cost of initial assembly, alignment, and calibration work.
I built a CNC Router table using bearings in this configuration. It used the 608 ball bearings with electrical conduit. turned out nice.
However, the loads justified the set up. Not much load on ED Heads. Then again, every bit of friction counts.
The very little inaccuracies can be handled by warming up the carriage using a heat gun.

description.text:
I found that the E3D V6 extruder works much better than the China-supplied "Mk8" for my Prusa i3.

So here is a mout that you can use. It works well with the printed carriage, like this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:586636

You'll need two screws, M3x35mm, washers, and nuts. I recommend printig everythig in ABS and actually using glue between the carriage and the mount. Mount the screws while the glue is still setting, and screw them tight, to get a good bond.
The parts have internal structure for strenght, but I recommend 20% infill or more to prevent bending from the tension of the screws.

The short triangle strut on the mount is on the bottom!
If you use a horizontal carriage with a center hole, you may try the vertical mount.

Mount your E3D V6 so the hoted-block points away from the carriage, and the fan is on the right (so it will not blow hot air on the carriage).

Ah... that's it, I guess!

And if you do print this, please share a photo, ok?

Update: New Revision (2016/09/10) on "https://pinshape.com/items/25939-3d-printed-water-jet-pump" This Water Jet Drive has been developed for a large sized boat. This jet drive can produce a flow rate roughly 192 L/m in my test setup (see below). With a exit velocity of 2.1 m/s. the aim was to create a high flow low pressure pump to have a lot of pushing force. Therefore an axial pump was the best suited solution.... 4 iterations later and i have created an outstanding pump. The only thing that will be changed is the prop, to a printed version.
The test setup:
  • using about 1 meter of 40mm high pressure pvc piping
  • 1x 90 degree elbow
  • 2x 15 degree bends
  • overall with a elevation difference of 400mm
    Power Plant
    using a 540 sized motor (3300kV) with a 3:1 gear box, driven by a 2 cell redback lipo.
    Prop
    bought a prop from the local hooby shop, the 2 bladed prop has an OD is 56mm with a 4mm thread centre.
    Shaft

description.text:
This is a labyrinth box. A labyrinth is basically a maze but without wrong turns. A box is typically a cube, this one is 2.15 x 2.15 x 2.15 inch (≈5.5x5.5x5.5cm). Thus we have a labyrinth box. There is also a small foot on one edge so that printing can be done cleanly without any support. The holes are 0.26 inch, thus any ball 0.25inch and smaller should work; personally I get about 0.010 undersizing on any hole printed, so I use a 0.22 inch steel bearing.

The idea came to me a few months back, I am sure I am not the first, that 3D printing provided a great opportunity for hidden features. Hidden features makes me think of great puzzle applications. From this idea, the labyrinth box was born.

The labyrinth is made of a 7x7x7 grid and is split into floors. In future iterations I will add 3D paths, but this labyrinth is essentially 2.5D. Originally I had designed a maze box, however, this proved to be much harder to solve than I expected, in particular because of the possibility of rouge threads of filament blocking the correct path. If wall thickness is reduced, then the internal features start to show on the outside face of the maze, losing its mystery.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

First use

Keep in mind that rouge threads of filament may be inside the labyrinth ways. If the bearing seems to get stuck, I would suggest shaking it hard to try to dislodge and otherwise, push to the side the offending obstruction.

I modeled this labyrinth in Solidworks and laid it out using a reference grid for all the dimensions. This enabled me to link all the dimensions to three main values that can be adjusted based on the desired wall spacing, wall thickness, and hole size. Thus, the labyrinth is very scalable in size. Revision to the floor-plans is very simple as well, all features are thin-walled and would only require single lines laid down on the base grid (or not if you feel compelled to make your life more complicated).

It would be amazing if the maze could be randomly generated. One could print a maze or labyrinth that has no map and has never been seen, however that is currently outside the scope of my experience.

remixed_from.title: Raj's Minimalistic Extruder MK1 for Printrbot

description.text: A printable replacement extruder for the printrbot plus V2. This is based on hammerFET's extruder and mixed with my Solidoodle mk5 extruder. Has all features required to attach belts, end stop screw, fan and hot end.

The original laser cut extruder on the Printrbot plus is very problematic. It is big, heavy, hard to load up, easily to misalign filament and the passage below the hobbed bolt is too wide, causing frequent filament buckles and jams for me. Instruction correspond to images.

  • Print the three parts at high infill for strength. Recommended settings are 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill and 3 perimeters.

  • Insert original linear bearings. It is recommended to wrap them in tape to ensure a tight fit and keep them aligned. Once in place, use a M3 bolt and nut to pull the carriage closed and trap them tightly.

  • The holes on the rear of the extruder are matched with the standard x belt tensioner. The other boss houses the standard x axis end stop bolt.

  • Secure the hot end with the original screws. The electronics plugs should face the left hand side.

  • Use a M3 bolt to secure the tension arm. Ensure it is tight but not so tight the arm can't pivot. Short M3 bolts secure the original fan.

  • Slide the extruder onto the 8mm x axis rods. Zig zag the x axis belt through the two holes at the rear and then use the wooden tensioner to tighten the belt properly.

  • The extruder stepper can now be bolted to the extruder, once again with the wires to the left. Plug everything in and tidy the wiring loom by wrapping it to the stepper. The upper filament guide bolts straight to the stepper with M3 bolts.

  • Use a M5 bolt to secure a 5x16x5mm bearing to the tension arm. Two washers can be placed either side of the bearing to center it. Slide on the filament drive onto the stepper shaft and align it with the filament bore in the extruder before tightening. A long M3 bolt with a matching nut and two washers tensions the arm. I used a spare spring but one of the original Wade's springs could be used it cut shorter.

  • Use Kapton tape on the extruder body behind the hot end to insulate it from melting. The z axis end stop screw may no longer be long enough, but one of the long screws left over from the Wade's extruder is an ideal longer length. Don't forget to wind it in to an appropriate length.

  • Two changes are needed in the firmware:
    • The extruder stepper logic must be inverted now that it is direct drive.
    • The extruder steps per mm will be far too large. My new setting ended up being 93 steps. Start with this, then request 100mm of filament through and measure how much actually goes through to adjust from there.

title: Elephant 3-layered-animal cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The 2.5D elephant is part of the three layered animal (tla) family. When build from beech plywood it's sturdy enough to be played by children. The birch plywood-version might be admired by adults for the naturalistic side-view and the explicit grain.

When scaling the size should be referenced by the width of a foot.

This build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. After machining it needed a little sanding and simple gluing together.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create (even) smaller versions.

Probably you could make a aluminum version and screw the parts together to get tiny key fob.

You can visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen/Tiere for more animals.

I searched the net for reference pictures and traced the vectors directly using Illustrator. Then I build the model in SketchUp to take a look at the design before wasting material.

The circles can be used for alignment and/or as screw-holes.

title: IKEA Not Lamp wall sconce mod

description.text:
The $8 Ikea "Not" lamp is a great cheap floor lamp, and I've got several at home. I realized though that a few of the lamps I have would be nicer if they didn't need to rest on the floor, so I designed and printed this simple bracket that allows you to mount one on your wall. Its 6 5/8" long so its no good for a MakerBot, but it fits great on my Ultimaker and I think RepRaps could do it too. Mine was printed with .35mm layer height (the "Low" quality profile in NetFabb) and 4.9mm infill spacing. Its a bit springy but I wanted a quick print to make sure it would even work. I'd recommend tighter infill like 2-3mm spacing for less springy-ness, which will be apparent when you switch it on, if you don't use a switched outlet. Ikea lamp is here:
http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/10139879/ But they have plenty of cheap wall sconces, so this is more for those who want to convert an existing lamp. I do want to say though that I'm pretty happy for coming up with a real useful 3D print here.

Print.
Unscrew the lamp just below where the power cord enters the tube. Press the tube into the hole, allowing the power cord grommet to slide into the slot. See the pictures if there's any question. My "Not" lamps are the older silver type, but I'm assuming the newer black ones are probably the same.
Screw to the wall with some standard drywall screws. Or come up with nicer looking screws.
Find a place to route the cord. (I should probably make this part of the thing but I imagine I won't get around to it)

comments.text: Ha! Nice. I was at IKEA the other day looking for a sconce that plugged in, but it seems all they have at the moment are fixtures. This might do the trick.

This is for the Pentax D-LI109 battery used in several of the Ricoh / Pentax DSLR cameras. such as the K-S1, K-S2, K-30, and K-50 cameras.

Not for the K1, K3, or K5 cameras. There is a different cover for the D-LI90 batteries used in the K1 and K3 cameras already on Thingiverse, which is where I got the idea.

I have both the K3 and K30 cameras. So I use both the D-LI90 and D-LI109 batteries. Plus I also carry extra batteries. This cover simply covers the contact end of the battery. Lithium batteries have been known to start fires. Covering the contacts reduces that risk.

author: CrisCG

description.text:
Remake of bdring's extruder mod.  Thank you bdring!  
This extruder block and lever is used with an mk7 style drive gear and McMaster-Carr pn 6138k64 bearing with 3/16 inch ID and 1/2 inch OD.  This extruder mod does not require sourcing any screws, which is its main benefit.  Simply push the bearing onto the printed shaft for a snug fit.  The design is mounted with the mk7 style drive gear set screw positioned away from the stepper motor so that the set screw rests on the stepper spindle flat to prevent slipping.  This method also reduces the lever arm with respect to the stepper's internal bearing and the filament contact position.  I adjusted the spring cavity for a spring that I was previously using.  I found it easier to rework the cad file than to look for a new spring.  
Thank you open source reprap community!

This is the base set for our Bizarchitecture terrain series, meant to represent the haunted, ever-shifting, living city of Cosmopolis from our tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder, though you could use it for any arcane/extra-planar ruins, This is in 15mm scale (our passion of the moment) but you can scale up by 120% for 18mm, or 180% for 28mm/Heroic scale gaming. The source models are available here in TinkerCAD, so if you want to hack them up/remix them, have at, but be sure and post remixes! I'll probably want to print whatever you make.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a carriage for the C-Bot printer that uses the E3D Titan Extruder. I have also included a file for an adapter in case you didn't buy the bowden adapter when you got the extruder. It is not really needed for this.

There are three models of the front carriage. One has a mount for an 8mm inductive approach sensor (18mm body). Another for the 4mm sensor (12mm body). The third one has no mount.

I have also include a mount for AK Erik's fan shroud, v2 (epfs_B02.stl). He has updated to v3, but I have not tested it to see how it fits with this. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1517120).

I have also included a file that can be mounted to the carriage to provide a wire tie mount point, if needed.

Several people have asked me about how my end stops work. The end stops are going to dependent on your printer. I included a couple pictures showing how I have my end stops mounted.

Using the modern wonder that is 3D printing, here we showcase 3D printed so-called "Lab-on-a-chip" (LOAC) microfluidic devices using computer assisted design (CAD) implemented in the relatively small scale and near instantaneous manufacturing process that 3D printing allows and indeed is continuing to improve all the time.

This shows that manufacturing these devices is not only cost-effective and practical for those who want to use such devices in a test bed fashion, (or even merely for demonstration), without having to commit to massive investment, both in terms of time and finances, but it also adds to the ability to procure such non-innocuous devices such as microfluidic cells which are often expensive and therefore not readily applicable to people who want to experiment with this interesting technology with a sense of taking a risk with an expensive piece of equipment.

The fact that the 3D printed CAD files can also be modified on site to perfect the device in function with its application, for example making the planar mixing element longer or wider on the circuit, is also the added benefit of having 3D printed devices such as this as more and more elements can be modified and incorporated into the device in tandem with experimental testing, creating an evolution of these devices with their certain applied niche in the laboratory.

The "μLab" Microfluidic Lab-on-a-Chip (LOAC) device itself is designed using Meshlab and can accept 4mm diameter barbed tubing connectors that can feed in liquids to the channel using commercially available 4mm diameter tubing.

We have also treated the interior of the our 3D printed LOAC with Silica Nanoparticles, giving the interior some of the properties of glassware, such as easy flow and cleaning hydrophobic and oleophobic properties. This allows for broader range of uses of this technology.

title: Cable Grommet for Desk or Dry-lining  (parametric)

description.text:
Having mounted my LED television on the wall I have a 80mm hole behind the TV, through which all the cables arrive.  No-one can see it of course, but I know it's there and it needs finishing, otherwise I might start muttering incoherently.  
It was designed in openscad and is fully parametric, it could doubtless be used for other purposes, including a desk grommet.  
Features

• Fully parametric (see instructions for source files)
  • Adjustable to fit any hole
  • Parameters includes choice of 4, 2 or 0 clips
  • Two part cap for easy insertion of cables
  • Cap and Grommet are in separate modules (within the same scad file) so easy to print separately

Download the OpenSCAD source file and edit with the measurements for your grommet. Compile and export as STL, then convert to gcodes in the usual way and send to your 3D printer. The two halves of the cap seem to stick together slightly, but I found it easy to separate them.

comments.text: Excellent design.  I had an idea for something similar, then found yours which is better than what I was thinking.  Thank you.
comments.author: Corey

comments.text: Got all the source files from your website, printed this in ABS with no raft or support.  It came out beautiful.  I like the way you select to generate a cap or grommet in the SCAD.  I made a much wider flange and put 4 tabs on it.  One notable thing is the number of tabs must be 2 or 4 (I tried 3 and it generated a part with 4 tabs).  I used it for the same purpose (70" Wallmounted TV installation in drywall) Thanks for a great design!  Better than the stuff thats commercially available.
comments.author: illuzion

comments.text: I'm so pleased that it's been useful to you! Yes the limitation of either 0, 2 or 4 tabs is intentional - I can't remember why now, but I am sure there was a good reason. Probably laziness :)

author: Racergirl

description.text:
If you’re like me, you spend a good portion of your day at a computer desk. Whether you’re a Gamer, Graphic Artist, or cubicle jockey, one of the hardest things to combat is desk clutter. Pens, paper, games, and cables are helplessly thrown across your workspace making it hard to not only find what you need, but also to keep things tidy. While there are many solutions for cable clutter, such as the IKEA Signum, It’s much harder to find a cheap, high quality, low profile hanger to keep those $200 Earphones.
The EarWigg hanger cost very little to produce as it uses a durable ABS plastic with a PVC wrapped cushion to provide a sturdy hanger for even those embarrassing Fostex RP 50’s. The mounting solution is a clamp type system that uses a square head bolt with a padded piston to hold securely on any desk without scarring, marking, or pitting. It features a swiveling base which allows it to be mounted on at any angle. An adhesive backed suede cutout will be used as a protectant to the clamp location. While other similar hangers exist, most use a flat screw design that easily strips, or do not provide a soft surface for your expensive studio grade headphones.

I really liked the original design by dutchy, but it just wasn't catching enough wind for me. So, I doubled the width of the blades without changing the length or the thickness (or the connector!). Making the blades catch more wind necessitated making the tail longer. While I was at it, I wanted it to take a beefier pole, so I changed that so that you can fit in on a 1" (max) diameter pole. I also flattened out the inside of both the mount and the hub so that I could fit a washer on each for added strength. Oh, I also added a cap on the hub, just to give it a "finished" look. You can see a comparison of the original and mine in two of the pictures (with mine obviously being the one with the wider blades).

Printed with PETG, since it's my favorite stuff.

Edit: I added an additional stl which you may, or may not need. I grabbed a pole that was 7/8" in diameter, so I made an adapter to be a press fit on that 7/8" pole with a .980 outside diameter to fit in the 1" hole in the mount and allow the spinner to turn easily with the wind.

Edit: Added an .980 outside diameter Adapter Topper which will mount to the top of any pole 1" diameter or less to fit in the 1" hole in the mount and allow the spinner to turn easily with the wind.

title: Replacement feet for Ryobi BT520 Table Saw

"So, who has a light source?"

Print this out, glue the lantern on and paint it up. It hugs the base of your PC's mini to show that she has a light source. I'd print out 3 at a time (or more) so that the stem on the stand doesn't get all "melty."

If you want a torch, use this one instead -- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1644921

Remixed from The Lantern - Warhammer Quest by onebitpixel

I was asked to make the lantern "solid" so I did and uploaded it here. Thanks again to onebitpixel. :)

I made the stand in SketchUp.

title: Mini Solar Powered Tesla Supercharger Station

description.text:
This is a mini supercharger station for your phones! Two chargers have Apple’s lighting connector for iPhone and one has micro USB for Android. The chargers are a remix of runeloken and don3sch designs on Thingiverse. I modified a few parts so they can print without supports. The white foam board was laser cut while the red details were 3D printed.

More info here: http://justinwilcott.com/mini-tesla-solar-powered-supercharger-station/
Sides: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1436193
Charger: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1413612
Solar panel: http://www.suaoki.com/product-g_7.html

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Only the front and back charger pieces really need a raft because they tend to peel up (side_01.stl, side_02.stl)

description.text: Filter / Funnel for 15ml and 50ml Falcon Tubes with screw thread. Place the filter mesh on the bottom of the top part, then screw together.

I created this completely parametric commander deckbox in Openscad, it was heavily based on -daniel-'s model.

Use this deckbox to show off your Commander while still keeping your cards completely safe!

You can change many parts of this box to fit exactly your needs. Have a ridiculously large deck made up of nothing but Relentless Rats and Swamps? Make "deckl' larger, etc. I know it looks terrible in the Customizer window, but I promise it works just fine!

To customize this, click on Apps and click Customizer, where you can then change the settings and it will generate a new model for you.

If you have a small build volume, separate the lid and box in a 3d modelling program.

Let me know if you have problems!

Remixes are welcome!

Enjoy!

description.text:
If you (or your kids) want to tote around their favorite crayons, why not carry them with a bit of class. This box is specifically fitted to carry 16 standard-size crayolas, each in its own compartment.

The top is a nice tight friction-fit, which should avoid spillage during transport. If you find that the standard lid is too tight a fit, try the "larger" lid, which allows an extra ~100 microns of ease.

description.text:
Back at it for another 300ZX part ! This is a Stud retainer for the 3rd brake light bar on a 1996 Nissan 300ZX. I was replacing the bar that was broken, really common problem on these, and ended up twisting the stud inside of the plastic retainer. Had to destroy the retainer to get the nut removed. Figured I would make one instead of ordering and waiting for another. There are only two of these on this part. I printed multiples in case I messed one up putting it back together. I did not need glue or anything to hold the stud in place as it was a really tight fit.

Printed without support by flipping the part on its end. Very little sagging due to the very short distance that needed bridged.Print settings were 3 shell, .2 layer height, no support, and 85% infill.

Let me know of any questions or concerns. Hope it helps =)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

85%

Notes:

I printed without support or raft. I just flipped the part on its end to eliminate the need for support.
Only cleanup was removal of a couple of sagged strands from the bridge.
Used Blender and the Boolean function. Took measurements with a digital caliper from the good remaining one.

title: DIY Light Project v2 - (high cooling performance)

description.text:
This is another version of my - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1282574 - made for the purpose of cooling an LED and driver exceptionally well within a simple and flexible build. I purchased an expensive UV diode and wanted to make sure it was well cooled and driven.

This design uses (2) 80mm CPU fans that will press fit into the body. There is ample room inside for drivers and other components, and the bottom is sized to fit a 50mm x 52mm heat sink.The pictured internals are an easy to DIY LM317 driver, 20V power supply, and (4) 10ohm resistors to drop the voltage to the fans. You'll need to print the body with supports but doesn't require much.

GL building!

title: 9V battery holder with momentary switch holder

description.text:
Helped my daughter create a poster for a concert she was attending and decided to add some LEDs. Needed a power supply. A 9V battery seemed most appropriate. So, created a holder for the battery that included space to mount a momentary switch, so she could turn the LEDs on the poster on and off. This is a remix from another excellent design. The switch was acquired from a local electronics shop for $0.99. I used a momentary N/O (normally off) type.

For assembly the 9V battery slides in and is firmly held in place by the arms. The switch slides down and rests on the part. It was hot-glued in place. Note - this was not a precision assembly job. However, results were ideal for the intended use.

title: 6mm OD PTFE Teflon Filament Tube Couplers / Joiners - Angled 30 + 45 Degrees

description.text: Here are curved filament tube couplers which can join two 6mm OD PTFE/Teflon filament tubes at a 30 or 45 degree angle. The filament tubes press fit into the coupler and should fit quite snug without deformation. The tubes insert ~12-14mm into each side for a good fit. These also work with the straight coupler I made that can be found here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1522776.

description.text:
This was made following the Tic Tac Box Challenge by DesignMakeTeach. When I read about it on twitter, I immediately thought that this was something for which I could make a design. I started thinking about what kinds of things could fit inside a Tic Tac container, and eventually thought of a Lego Minifigure.
I originally thought adding a 2x4 lego strip onto the design would suffice, but it ended up being a bit to wide to fit well. So I cut the 2x4 strip down to 1x4, centered it, and made this design.

The design with _v1 at the end is actually not centered, though. It's a little bit off. At first, I considered this pointless, but I'm thinking having the strip offset in the y dimension might be helpful for either having the guy hold up his hands or to fit a flowing cape. the _v1 design is not very off-centered, though, and might not make a considerable difference. I printed one off and will update this after some testing. The _v2 file is centered.

I then repaired it in netfabb basic; the original had shells around each individual part, netfabb combined them into one. It shouldn't have any weird holes or whatnot. Let me know if you problems design-side.

The idea is to have a fun way of displaying your cool, custom Lego minifigures using something you might normally throw away; a Tic Tic container!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Don't remember

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you have a printer with some bridging issues, I would suggest trying printing at a higher infill. When it was printing, it did some weird things when I got to the top part of the infill. The TAZ was able to do it, but I don't know if it would turn out the same way with other printers. Something to consider.

I also printed this in High-impact Polysterene (HIPS) which may mean it turned out differently than a print in ABS or PLA would.

I didn't need to do any post-printing work. I used the "High Detail" print profile in Cura and had no issues with having to sand the piece down. I did put a minifigure onto the Lego strip immediately, figuring that it might be able to shape the hot plastic into better fitting the inside of the little leg holes. It was a tight fit for me, so adjusting with sand paper might be beneficial if the fit is too loose.

The actual lid portion fit very snuggly into a tic tac box container!I usually have to use a fingernail between the model and the container to get them apart, which I think was just enough force to keep it together without making it impossible to pull apart.

I used the Chrome App 3D Design soemthing. I like the ease of use for the Boolean functions this program has. I used DesignMakeTeach's original design of the Tic Tac Box lid and orb74's design of a Lego 2x4 to create this model. I will be adding the individual components into a TinkerCad project so that other people can edit them if they would like (move the Lego strip around or whathaveyou)

This guide is for Windows Users. I am growing to love OpenSCAD as a creative tool for 3D design but I do find that it's text editor lacks many of the basic features that I appreciate when writing code... Namely: Auto-Completion
Syntax Highlighting
Collapsible Outline levels
Line Numbering
Automatic Tabbing
Search and Replace
Block Tabbing using the tab key. I was pleased to discover however that you don't need to put up with the standard text editor. There is a feature that allows you to conveniently use the text editor of your choice with OpenSCAD. My editor of choice is Notepad++ a fast well featured open source text editor. You can download it from http://notepad-plus-plus.org/ Notepad++ supports many different programming languages but not unfortunately OpenSCAD. It does however have the facility that allows you to create your own language file which I have included here. This is definitely a work in progress as I have had to make a few compromises due to the limitations of Notepad++'s language editor. I dare say other more experienced coders opinions will differ as to how best to syntax code the OpenSCAD language. I am currently working on adding auto-complete functionality to notepad++ as we speak. I have included a working though not complete file called openscad_removethisbitandcopy.xml. Currently most if not all functions will auto-complete, what is going to take me longer is adding call-tips to all the functions which would be nice though is not critical. ** Edits ***
13/5/2012 Added extension type to openscad.xml so that Notepad++ will now automatically detect language when .scad files are opened. Thankyou CrazyJaw, saved me some time there.

Installing The Language File I assume that you have already downloaded and installed both OpenSCAD and Notepad++

  • Download the openscad.xml file.

  • Open Notepad++

  • In the view menu pick the User-Defined Dialogue... item

  • In a moment the User-Defined dialogue box will appear. Select Import

  • The Open dialogue box will appear, navigate to where you downloaded the openscad.xml file and open it.

  • That should be the openscad language file installed. You cna check by looking under the Language menu in Notepad++. At the bottom should be Openscad.
    • Using Notepad++ With OpenSCAD

  • Open OpenSCAD, Create a new file and save it.

  • In the Design menu select Automatic Reload and Compile

  • In the View menu select Hide editor

  • Leaving OpenSCAD running, now find your newly created .scad file in Windows Explorer, right hand click on it and select Edit with Notepad++

  • Arrange both OpenSCAD and Notepad++ on your screen/s so that both can be seen at once. If you are using Windows Vista or 7 you can drag the title bars of the applications to the left and right sides of the screens to do this easily.

  • Edit your .scad file in Notepad++. Each time you save the file (CTRL+S) you will see that OpenSCAD will recompile the object. You will need to choose the Openscad language from the Languages menu. You will also need to either modify the color scheme for the language file or chose a dark theme for notepad itself.
    • Enjoy all the advanced text editing features of Notepad++ as well as syntax highlighting of your code!!! Enabling Auto-Completion in Notepad++

  • Download the file named openscad_removethisbitandcopy.xml and copy it into either c:\Program Files\Notepad++\plugins\APIs (Windows 32bit) or C:\Program Files (x86)\Notepad++\plugins\APIs (Windows 64bit) or something like that depending on your setup.

  • Rename the .xml file to openscad.xml

  • Restart notepad and try it out. Auto-Complete can be activated by clicking CTRL-Space at any time.

  • If you want Auto-Complete to be even more automatic, you can turn it on so that it will detect the functions as you type them... Go to Settings and click Preferences.

  • When the dialogue box appears, select the Backup/Auto-Completions tab. Under the Auto-Completion section choose your preferred options.

description.text:
This uses http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:651469, or another 20mm round spinning thing with a 5mm bore. This was designed for my Tevo Tarantula, but can probably be used on most any 2040 extrusion as a idler. The design uses a m5 nut, 25mm m5, 2 m4x10 and t nuts, for the printed pulley you need two 626 bearings and 2 1mm spacers. The design has tight tolerances, but I was able to fit everything together easy enough. You can set the m5 with the 25mm if you need to.

Please post your makes, or pic of the rig with the parts if you use it. Thanks!

description.text:
I was using the camera mount from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1006864 which worked great. Until I added a dual fan modification. That mount centers the camera on the bed, so when you have a fan in front of the camera and print in the center of the bed, you get an excellent view or video of the fan.

In this re-mix (more of a reimplementation inspired by), I move the arm off to the far right side of the bed. I also change the top mounting plate to be a separate piece, so it can be pointed toward the center of the bed and be adjustable. The picture of the dual fan and nozzle is an Octoprint screen capture of the view from the mounted camera when the nozzle is at the center of the bed.

The arm has an M6 captive nut, so you'll have to pause the print at the appropriate point to add the nut. After printing, use an M6 bolt to attach the top plate to the arm. Use a bolt and the existing screw hole in the right front of the mount to attach the arm to the bed. I reused the camera mount spacer from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1006864.

title: Wrist pad for ErgoDox Inifinity keyboard

description.text:
This is a wristpad I designed for my ErgoDox Inifinity keyboard kit. Only one model (STL file) is provided. It will fit the right side of the ErgoDox. To print a corresponding left side it is recommended that you use your host/slicer software to rotate the model 180 degrees around the y-axis, or alternatively mirror the model along the x-axis.

I recommend printing this model in the orientation it will normally lay, ensuring that the bottom surface contacts the print bed. Depending on printer quality and layer height printing the pad at another orientation may make it difficult to adhere rubber feet to the pad without using a strong adhesive (see Post-Printing instructions).

The provided 3D model will probably work with other models of ErgoDox keyboards (like the ErgoDox EZ), but I have not tested this assumption. If the fit is not right for your model of ErgoDox let me know the problem and I can make the design work in the Customizer. It would be most helpful if you could provide an image showing how the model and your keyboard fail to fit together properly.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Finishing

I find the feeling of a freshly printed top surface on my palms/wrists to be uncomfortable and distracting. So I would recommend some form of smoothing using either sandpaper, acetone, or smoothing epoxy like XTC-3D.

Finally, put some rubber feet on the bottom side to keep the wrist pads from sliding around on you. The design is meant to account for height added by rubber feet. If you decide not to use rubber feet you may find that the height of the model doesn't feel quite right.

If rubber feet do not stick well to the bottom of the wrist pad then super glue or another strong bonding adhesive may be used to ensure the feet stay in place.

If no rubber feet are available you may cut rubber bands into strips and use adhesive to add no-slip rubber strips to the bottom of the wrist pads.

description.text:
Soporte para tornillo de banco con posibilidad de rotar, una vez fijada la posición se aprietan un poco las tuercas y queda rígido como para dar martillazos, limar o taladrar.
Ocupa 176mm para un tornillo con una base de 136mm de diámetro, lleva 5 tornillos M10, con 6 arandelas y 5 tuercas, he usado 3 tuercas autoblocantes para los tornillos del soporte y 2 normales para el bloqueo.

title: Evolv DNA75 Box Mod - Bottom Feeder (Squonk)

description.text:
This is for left squonkers, if u like right squonk that simple "mirror" body and front panel on the X plane.

External size are: 88x25x53.
Two version of body: 10 or 12 mm drip cap hole.

To mount u need:

  • 9 magnets 3x2 mm;
  • 10 magnets 3x1 mm;
  • drip cap (10 or 12 mm hole);
  • round bottle (18 mm);
  • DNA75;
  • some wire;
  • battery contacts (i use keystone 5209): on Amazon http://fave.co/2bsgxvX;
  • 3x M1.6x5 or M2x5 to fix the dna75.

Update 21/05/2016

  • reupload body STL
  • reupload front_panel STL

Update 22/05/2016

  • released

Update 24/05/04

  • added lateral_panel_v2: with this the screen is more stable (see last picture)
